AI coding tools: a Faustian bargain for your skills

Why I think AI coding assistants are different from any other programming support tool

13 April 2025
Opinion
Software Engineering
13 April 2025

Who am I?

Hi, I am Giovanni, a ML engineer working on biomedical applications of machine learning and AI. Creating pipelines to manipulate data and train models takes up most of my normal workdays. You can read more about it in the About Me page.

Why should you care about my opinions and ideas? There's plenty of essays and opinions online, but I like to think that I am gaining enough firsthand experience to offer some worthwhile insights. I'll leave the truth of that to your judgment.

And as a standard disclaimer, all the opinions expressed here are solely my own.

TLDR summary

I believe that AI coding assistants are different from any previous programming support tool, not just in an incremental/quantitative way, but qualitatively as well. In my opinion this difference is a negative for your skills as a software engineer.

The crux of the matter: AI tools are qualitatively different

I see a lot of discussion surrounding the use of coding assistants like Github Copilot, Cursor AI, and Claude Sonnet. Depending on whom you ask, they are either the best invention since the personal computer, or they are the worst overhyped garbage since NFTs.

A common criticism leveraged against these tools is that their use atrophies your skills, to which the standard response is that they are just the natural improvement of LSP suggestions and code snippets, and that these addons that we now take for granted do exactly the same thing. Essentially, many claim that the difference between an AI assistant and a language server is just a quantitative step, that they are the same thing and AI is simply a better version.

My claim is exactly the opposite:

AI assistants are qualitatively different from any other coding tool. While language servers confirm and correct the answer you already know, AI tools create an answer from scratch.

I use code completion and syntax lookup a lot in my everyday life, and sometimes I struggle to imagine what coding would be like without them. But whenever I engage with them, it is always to refine the details of something that is alreay mostly formed in my mind. Was the correct numpy function to concatenate two arrays concat or concatenate? In what order should I provide the arguments to json.dump, was the file pointer first or should it be the object to serialize?

These are all things that I know, but that might need a refresher if I have not used them in a while. More importantly, though, they are not things that will make me a significantly better programmer if I know them by heart (althought you should know them by heart if you use them frequently). Compare this to the usage of something like Copilot, where it can take over and offer you a complete piece of code before you have even fully thought through what comes next. This process may skip right through the details of the code that you are not too familiar with, and once a problem arises you will probably be stuck. You can see this in practice by looking at the "work" of those that take vibe coding seriously.

Imagine you are planning a trip to another city; using a language server, to me, is like stopping to ask somebody "is this the right way to the train station?", while AI tools are just like getting out of your house and asking somebody "how do I get to Rome?".

Why I stopped using AI assistants

In the past year, I have given a good try to a few of these tools. Mostly I tried to use Github Copilot, because that is the assistant allowed in my workplace. The results for me have ranged from underwhelming to outright terrible, not just in the quality of the code, but more so in what they changed in me.

One of the moments that crystallized my opinion on AI assistants came as I was writing a script for a quick and dirty baseline model, and Copilot helpfully chimed in with a pretty large chunk of code. My brain simply went "yeah, that looks about right", and accepted the suggestion. Wrapping up the script, I ran it with a test case, and it failed miserably. After checking the code, I realised that, while the code looked correct, it would not interface at all with the rest of the script. I had inadvertently added to my script the code equivalent of the six-digit hand found in AI-generated images.

Copilot had pushed my brain into "Lgtm" mode, and I profoundly disliked that. After that episode, I stopped using AI assistants entirely, because in my opinion

AI coding assistants can never make you a better software engineer. At their best, you are buying speed at the cost of skill and knowledge.

But what about using them as a chat/to summarize documentation/to explain the code?. To me none of these use cases invalidate the previous point. If you want mastery over an area of knowledge, details matter, edge cases matter, nuance matters. And a proper appreciation of them comes from experience, from repeatedly doing the boring thing. If you practice reading code, you will get better and faster at understanding someone else's code. If you practice scouring the documentation, you will get good at parsing knowledge from documentation. All of these are transferable skills that I will use over and over in my career, that I can bring with me to any new project or environment. I chose to invest in me, and in building up the skillset I want future me to have and be proud of.

Ah but Copilot sucks, you should try XYZ (at the time of writing it's always Claude Sonnet 3.7). Again, at best I may get better results for my immediate task, and I will be worse off for the next one. If some day AI tools are just that good, I will have to learn to use them or simply open a bakery once they take over. But that day is not today, and using the currently available tools will not make me any better at using these hypothetical perfect tools, since it's highly unlikely they will look anything like what we have now.

Well, for me they are great, I use them everyday. I am glad for you, and I hope they simplify your work. If you are the kind of person that prioritizes creating a product over becoming better at writing software, then these tools may be exactly what you need. But they are just not for me. Maybe you can find some compromise, e.g. turning AI assistants of two days a week to keep sharp, but to me the advantages are not worth the hassle.

I am an amateur piano player, and I am very aware that the skills necessary to play something that amazes your audience are built on top of endless repetitions of boring chores. After you do your scales, your arpeggios, you play a piece slowed down over and over, only then you are ready for the real deal. To me building software is much the same: if you want to be that insanely knowledgeable and capable senior dev, you have to be willing to put in the work that annoys you. Until AI coding assistants are good enough to replace me completely, I will not take this bargain and give up on my development.
